bad_faith_indicators: No refund or itemization after 45+ days
Zero communication about deposit after deadline passed

next_steps.notes: Under § 92.107, the clock runs from when the landlord receives your forwarding address.

defenses.title: Landlord Must Prove Claims
defenses.key_point: Under Texas law, a landlord who withholds or deducts from a deposit must provide a written itemized list of deductions (§ 92.104). The burden is on the landlord to document and justify each charge. General or vague claims without itemization or supporting receipts are difficult to enforce. Additionally, since the 30-day deadline has passed, any belated itemization may be viewed less favorably under § 92.109.
what_to_ask_landlord: Please provide a written, itemized list of all deductions with specific amounts
Please provide receipts for any repairs or professional services charged
Please provide before and after photos documenting the claimed damage
evidence_helpful: All documentation showing you left the property in reasonable condition
Lease agreement showing what you agreed to

damage_defense.strategic_note: No specific damage concerns detected from your notes. The burden-of-proof defense applies to any deductions the landlord may claim.
damage_defense.disclaimer: These defense points are informational only and based on general principles. Specific legal strategies should be discussed with a licensed Texas attorney.

leverage_points.title: 30-Day Deadline Passed — No Return or Itemization of $1,000 Deposit
leverage_points.why_this_matters: Your landlord has held your $1,000 deposit for 50 days without returning it or providing any written explanation of deductions. Texas Property Code § 92.103 requires landlords to act within 30 calendar days—that deadline passed 20 days ago. Under § 92.109, a landlord who fails to meet this deadline may lose the right to withhold any portion of the deposit and may be liable for additional amounts.

supporting_facts.fact: 50 days have elapsed (deadline exceeded by 20 days)

recommended_steps.description: Send a written demand letter to your landlord via certified mail (return receipt requested). Include: your name, former property address, move-out date (2025-12-30), deposit amount ($1,000), your current mailing address, and a request for immediate return of the full deposit or a complete written itemization of any deductions. Keep copies of the letter and your certified mail receipt.

Write out a simple timeline: your move-out date, when you provided your forwarding address, any communications with your landlord, and today's date. This is important documentation if you need to escalate.

leverage_points.title: Forwarding Address Not Yet Provided — 30-Day Clock May Not Have Started
leverage_points.why_this_matters: Texas Property Code § 92.107 indicates that a landlord's obligation to return a deposit is tied to receiving the tenant's forwarding address. If you have not provided a forwarding address in writing, the 30-day refund deadline may not yet have started. Sending your address now creates a clear paper trail and starts the clock.

supporting_facts.fact: Forwarding address not yet provided to landlord in writing

recommended_steps.description: Send your forwarding address today via certified mail with return receipt. Include your full name, the former property address, your move-out date (2025-12-30), and your new mailing address. Keep the certified mail receipt—it documents when you sent it and when the landlord received it.

The 30-day deadline runs from when the landlord receives your forwarding address. Note the delivery date on your certified mail receipt and count 30 days from that date. If no refund or itemization arrives by day 30, a written demand would be appropriate.

procedural_steps.title: Gather Your Documents
procedural_steps.description: Collect everything related to your rental in one place: (1) your signed lease, (2) move-in condition report or photos, (3) move-out photos, (4) deposit payment receipt, (5) any emails, texts, or letters with your landlord, (6) proof of forwarding address delivery if sent.
checklist: Forwarding address proof (certified mail receipt if applicable)

procedural_steps.title: Send a Written Demand Letter
procedural_steps.description: Send a written demand letter to your landlord via certified mail (return receipt requested). Include: your name, former property address, move-out date (2025-12-30), deposit amount ($1,000), your current mailing address, and a request for immediate return of the full deposit or a complete written itemization of any deductions. Keep copies of the letter and your certified mail receipt.

procedural_steps.title: Document Your Timeline
procedural_steps.description: Write out a simple timeline: your move-out date, when you provided your forwarding address, any communications with your landlord, and today's date. This is important documentation if you need to escalate.

procedural_steps.title: Send Your Forwarding Address
procedural_steps.description: Send your forwarding address today via certified mail with return receipt. Include your full name, the former property address, your move-out date (2025-12-30), and your new mailing address. Keep the certified mail receipt—it documents when you sent it and when the landlord received it.

procedural_steps.title: Mark the 30-Day Start Date
procedural_steps.description: The 30-day deadline runs from when the landlord receives your forwarding address. Note the delivery date on your certified mail receipt and count 30 days from that date. If no refund or itemization arrives by day 30, a written demand would be appropriate.

procedural_steps.title: Learn About Your Options
procedural_steps.description: If your written demand is not resolved, Texas Justice of the Peace courts handle small claims up to $20,000. Filing fees are typically $50-100. You may also consult with a licensed Texas attorney.
